contentrichtext.text: {{Infobox MLB player |image= |name=Julio Machado |position=[[Pitcher]] |bats=Right |throws=Right |birth_date={{Birth date and age|1965|12|1}} |birth_place=[[San Carlos del Zulia]], [[Venezuela]] |debutdate=September 7 |debutyear={{By|1989}} |debutteam=New York Mets |finaldate=October 6 |finalyear={{By|1991}} |finalteam=Milwaukee Brewers |stat1label=[[Win-loss record (pitching)|Win–loss record]] |stat1value=7-5 |stat2label=[[Earned run average]] |stat2value=3.12 |stat3label=[[Strikeout]]s |stat3value=151 |teams=<nowiki></nowiki> *[[New York Mets]] (1989–90) *[[Milwaukee Brewers]] (1990–91) }} {{spanish name|Machado|Rondón}} '''Julio Segundo Machado Rondón''' (December 1, 1965 in [[San Carlos del Zulia]], [[Venezuela]]) is a former [[Major League Baseball]] right-handed [[relief pitcher]] who played for the [[New York Mets]] (1989–90) and [[Milwaukee Brewers]] (1990–91). Machado started his career with the Mets. In the {{By|1990}} season, he went to the Brewers in a four-player deal, along with [[pitcher]] [[Kevin Brown (left-handed pitcher)|Kevin Brown]], in exchange for [[catcher]] [[Charlie O'Brien]] and a [[minor league baseball|minor league]] player. Machado had a decent [[fastball]], good control and willingness to challenge hitters. He also pitched a better-than-average [[curveball]] and a [[slider]]. Machado was certainly good enough to pitch for a few more years. However, he is a footnote in the ledger of baseball history. Spending the 1991 off-season in his homeland, Machado was arrested for murder being accused of shooting a woman following an auto accident. He was convicted and, following appeals, Machado was sentenced to 12 years in 1996.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://news.google.com/newspapers?id=fO4bAAAAIBAJ&sjid=AFMEAAAAIBAJ&pg=2686,4153158&dq=julio+machado+murder&hl=en | title=Ex-pitcher sentenced | publisher = The Dispatch | date=1996-08-16}}</ref> In a three-year career, Machado posted a 7–5 record with 151 [[strikeout]]s and a 3.12 [[earned run average|ERA]] in 147 [[innings pitched|innings]]. Machado went on to play in the Venezuelan winter league and currently coaches in that league. ==See also== * [[List of players from Venezuela in Major League Baseball]] ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== {{Baseballstats|br=m/machaju01 |fangraphs= |cube= |brm=}} {{Persondata <!-- Metadata: see [[Wikipedia:Persondata]]. --> | NAME = Machado, Julio | ALTERNATIVE NAMES = | SHORT DESCRIPTION = Venezuelan baseball player | DATE OF BIRTH = December 1, 1965 | PLACE OF BIRTH = San Carlos del Zulia, Venezuela | DATE OF DEATH = | PLACE OF DEATH = }} {{DEFAULTSORT:Machado, Julio}} [[Category:Major League Baseball pitchers]] [[Category:Milwaukee Brewers players]] [[Category:New York Mets players]] [[Category:Peninsula Pilots players]] [[Category:Jackson Mets players]] [[Category:Spartanburg Suns players]] [[Category:St. Lucie Mets players]] [[Category:Spartanburg Phillies players]] [[Category:Reading Phillies players]] [[Category:Tidewater Tides players]] [[Category:Clearwater Phillies players]] [[Category:Major League Baseball players from Venezuela]] [[Category:People from Zulia]] [[Category:1965 births]] [[Category:Living people]] {{Venezuela-baseball-pitcher-stub}}
